In the elderly, we need to look for non-psychiatric co-morbidities (pain, cardiovascular pathologies, cancers, neurological and neurodegenerative diseases, etc.) as well as psychiatric ones (anxiety disorders, addictions, personality disorders, etc.).

The clinical examination should look for pain, faecal impaction, a bladder globe, infection, etc.

Complementary tests depend on the presenting symptoms: CBC, blood ionogram, blood calcium, blood albumin, TSH, vitamins B9-B12, ECG, kidney and liver function, urine dipstick, protid, blood albumin, blood sugar, chest X-ray, brain imaging, etc.

question.title: What should be included in the clinical examination of the elderly?
question.description: The clinical examination should look for

option_a.title: Only psychiatric disorders
option_a.description: This option is incorrect, as the clinical examination should look for both psychiatric and non-psychiatric co-morbidities

option_b.title: Only physical pathologies
option_b.description: This option is incorrect, as the clinical examination should look for both psychiatric and non-psychiatric co-morbidities

option_c.title: Pain, faecal impaction, and bladder globe
option_c.description: This option is correct, as these are examples of non-psychiatric co-morbidities to look for in the clinical examination

option_d.title: Only blood tests
option_d.description: This option is incorrect, as the clinical examination should include a combination of physical examination and laboratory tests

correct_option.title: Pain, faecal impaction, and bladder globe
